[H1] Classification of Immune Mediated Tissue Injury: Gell Coombs Classification.
[H1] The four types of hypersensitivity reaction.
[H1] Antibody-Mediated Cell and Tissue Injury: IgE Mediated Hypersensitivity Reactions.
To understand the pathophysiologic mechanisms associated with Type I anaphylactic hypersensitivity reactions
[LIST_ITEM] The role of IgE-mediated Mast cell degranulation in Type I reactions
[LIST_ITEM] The primary effector mediators released during Mast cell stimulation
[LIST_ITEM] The pathologic changes observed in tissues associated with anaphylactic hypersensitivity reactions
[LIST_ITEM] The modulatory role of eosinophils in these reactions
[LIST_ITEM] To correlate the effect of mediators on target organs with the clinical expression of anaphylactic reactions
[LIST_ITEM] Type I reactions are usually the result of exposure to environmental allergens in genetically susceptible individuals
[LIST_ITEM] 1/10 persons in USA affected to varying degrees
[LIST_ITEM] Genetics not clearly defined, although there is a familial association
[LIST_ITEM] Atopy: a genetic predisposition for developing IgE responses to many antigens
[LIST_ITEM] Pollens, molds, house dust mite, animal dander
Induction and effector mechanisms in Type I Hypersensitivity
[H1] Degranulation and release of preformed mediators.
Leukotrienes (C4, D4, E4) Prostaglandins Platelet activating factor Cytokines
Resting mast cell shows granules containing serotonin and histamine
Multivalent antigen crosslinks bound IgE antibody causing release of granule contents
[H1] Effects of Mediators in Anaphylaxis: Reversible Response.
[LIST_ITEM] Histamine - vascular permeability, vasodilation (post-capillary venule), smooth muscle contraction
[H1] Effects of Mediators in Anaphylaxis: Reversible Response (cont.).
[LIST_ITEM] Leukotriene C4, D4, E4 - smooth muscle contraction
[H1] Effects of Mediators in Anaphylaxis: Reversible Response (cont.).
[LIST_ITEM] Lipid Mediators: PAF - platelet activating factor - low molecular weight lipid
[LIST_ITEM] Type 1 response: up to 10%+ circulating leukocytes
[H1] Pathologic Changes Associated with Anaphylactic Reactions: Reversible.
[LIST_ITEM] Symptoms depend on target organ: skin
[LIST_ITEM] Gross: swelling, wheal and flare response
[LIST_ITEM] Electron microscopic: edema, endothelial cell gaps
[H1] Pathologic Changes Associated with Anaphylactic Reactions: Reversible.
[LIST_ITEM] leukotriene inhibitors: lipase inhibitors, receptor antagonists
|  Hypersensitivity Type | Time | Features  | | --- | --- | --- | |  Type 1 | Minutes | Wheal: edema Flare: vasodilation Eosinophils  |
[H1] Serologic Tests: RAST - Radioallergosorbent Test - Specific IgE.
[H1] The four types of hypersensitivity reaction.
cytotoxic action antibody complement complement mediated lysis target cell
type III immune-complex deposition complement tissue basement membrane
type IV antigens inflammatory mediators lymphokines activated macrophage
[LIST_ITEM] Cytotoxic or Type II Reactions: Binding of Antibody (IgG or IgM) with cell membrane or tissue antigens
[LIST_ITEM] Red blood cell membrane antigens - hemolytic anemias
[LIST_ITEM] Platelet antigens - thrombocytopenia cell membrane - petechial hemorrhage
[H1] Rh Incompatibility in Newborn: Hemolytic Anemia.
Preventative Therapy: Block sensitization by giving mother anti-D (Rho) Immunoglobulin within 72 hours after first birth or abortion
[LIST_ITEM] Antibody directed to tissue antigens: examples
[LIST_ITEM] Goodpasture’s syndrome: antigen = basement membrane of kidney and lung
[LIST_ITEM] Dermatitis Herpetiformis: antigen = epidermis basement membrane reticulin
[LIST_ITEM] Bullous Pemphigoid: antigen = epidermis basement membrane
[LIST_ITEM] Pemphigus vulgaris: antigen = epidermis keratinocyte membranes
[LIST_ITEM] Immunofluorescence: immunoglobulin and complement deposition; linear immunofluorescence
[LIST_ITEM] Electron microscopy: no electron dense deposits
[LIST_ITEM] Complement → ▽ C3b deposition ↓ C3a + C5a Proteases ↓
[LIST_ITEM] ← PMN recruitment reactive oxygen metabolites ↓ tissue injury
Lung: hemorrhage, hemoptysis, alveolar infiltrates Kidney: proteinuria, hematuria, renal failure
[LIST_ITEM] Linear secondary anti-human antibody to IgG or complement containing a fluorescent marker
[LIST_ITEM] Antibody Binds to Cell Receptor (Type V Reactions)
[LIST_ITEM] Hyperthyroidism (Grave’s Disease): Thyroid follicle cell - IgG antibody binds to thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor and stimulates cell
[LIST_ITEM] Myasthenia Gravis: antibody to acetylcholine receptor at neuromuscular synapse antibody blocks neuromuscular transmission (decreased receptors) causing muscle weakness
A. STIMULATE CELL B. BLOCK BINDING OF NATURAL LIGAND
[H1] The four types of hypersensitivity reaction.
Type III: Immune Complex Mediated Tissue Injury
[H1] Summary: Immune Complex Mediated Tissue Injury.
[H1] Type III Hypersensitivity: Local I.C. Disease.
[LIST_ITEM] Immunofluorescence: immunoglobulin and complement deposition, granular immunofluorescence pattern
[LIST_ITEM] Clinical - depends on target organ and/or site of immune complex deposition
[LIST_ITEM] Irregular secondary anti-human antibody to IgG or complement containing a fluorescent marker
[LIST_ITEM] Skin tests for Type III reactions
[LIST_ITEM] Elimination of antigen - as in transfusion reactions, hypersensitivity lung reactions to foreign antigens, and certain drug reactions
[H1] The four types of hypersensitivity reaction.
[LIST_ITEM] To define the primary mechanisms involved in contact hypersensitivity and delayed type hypersensitivity reactions
[LIST_ITEM] To review mechanisms of T-Cell mediated cytotoxicity (see Dr. King)
[LIST_ITEM] Mononuclear inflammatory cells: lymphocytes, monocytes/macrophages and antigen presenting cells
| | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | |   |  reaction time | clinical appearance | histological appearance | antigen  |

|  contact | 48–72 hours | eczema | infiltration of lymphocytes and, later, macrophages, oedema of epidermis | epidermal: e.g. nickel, rubber, poison ivy usually a hapten  | |  tuberculin | 48–72 hours
| local hardening and swelling ± fever | infiltration of lymphocytes, monocytes, and macrophages | intradermal injection used diagnostically: tuberculin, mycobacterial and leishmanial antigens

| |  granulomatous | 4 weeks | hardening e.g. in skin or lung | granuloma containing epithelioid cells, giant cells, and macrophages; fibrosis ± necrosis | persistent Ag or Ag–Ab complexes in macrophages; or 'non-immunological', e.g talcum powder  |
The elicitation phase of contact hypersensitivity
[LIST_ITEM] Antigen expressed with Class I MHC
[LIST_ITEM] FAS-induced apoptosis: CD8+ T cell: FAS ligand target cell: FAS receptor
[LIST_ITEM] Tumor Necrosis Factor α and β
[H1] The four types of hypersensitivity reaction.
cytotoxic action antibody complement complement mediated lysis target cell
type III immune-complex deposition complement blood vessel tissue basement membrane
type IV antigens inflammatory mediators lymphokines activated macrophage
